Wheras I was enjoined by her

at
according to

ch

s of

24 of June, and 10 of July.
The 19 of July I had one from yo
r
L. of
e 7 of the

ch
was
e first
at I receaved from
the time of my departure: wherein yo
w
made me no
answear to
e principal point of my forsaid l
re
s,
but onely willed me in it, to rec
o
mend unto
e states
certaine special demaundes, w
ch
her Ma
tie
in person had
delivered
M
r
Caron
: of w
ch
no copie was sent unto
me, nor any note or specification, to w
at
effect they
might tend. Nevertheles to execut my charge, I
caused
e states to assemble upon it, and after I had
used some speeches unto them, to hasten their assistance,
I desired their answear to
e forsaid demaundes,
But they in their answear declared unto me, that
as yet they had no notice of any demaundes, and
therfore they required me, to exhibit them in writing,
or to signifie by worde, w
at
mater they contained.
And when they founde by my replie, that I was igno-
rant altogether of
at w
ch
I required I leave to be consi-
dered, what they thought among themselves, and howe
ill it did beseeme me, to come to them in their mee-
ting, to inquire her Hig
es
pleasure: especially in those
causes, w
ch
they expected from me, and for w
ch
her
Ma
tie
sent me purposely, to negotiat w
t
e
Provinces
.
The 20 day of July, they heard from M
r
Caron, and
receaved those demaundes w
ch
were made by her Ma
tie
:
in w
ch
they founde divers doubtes of special import
a
ce,
w
ch
they deputed certaine persons to communicat w
t
me at my lodging, supposing, as it seemed, that I had
also then receaved
full instructions in every point.

But perceaving, as before,
at I was a stranger to
the
mater, they themselves acquainted me w

r

letters, and w

ch

dver-

at by order of her Hig

the forsaid demaundes was countermanded. And w
ithall
they made shewe to be greatly moved, being left in s
ome

at by my relation they knewe nothing, [.]
by their Agent, but uncertaintie. Wherupon they re
quired
me to
use
some diligence, to learne her Hig
es
last and deter
mi-
nat purpose, aswell in respect of
at w
ch

ould
perfourme, as also of
at w
ch
she required of them: t
o the

rame
e course of their provisions, for

inces
and
e best advancem
t
of

t

es, as

le to
drawe

rise.
Of this I certified yo
r

nce

forces my

ance,

ed

r

: by meanes wherof, and

full in-

e states: who urged me continually to
an orderly proceeding, by proposing roundly to them
and in her Ma
ties
name, as I had ever bin wonted,
her determinat pleasure.
The 8 of Sep
t

r
L. answear bearing
date
e 27 of Au
g
by w
ch
yo
w
seemed muche offen-
ded, charging me w
t
prescisenesse, and cavillation,
and w
t
some not e of worse dealing, then my long and
faithfull service had any way deserved, or yo
r
L.
I trust, doth conceave at this p
nt
. And although
in that letter there was nothing contained, that the
states expected, and I had written for so often, yet
by earnest solicitation I obtained so muche, as they
dispatched then p
nt
ly six shippes well appointed,
and other three they promised to send p
nt
